scenario.setup: Attorney at a mid-size firm transitioning into data privacy practice. Has a few months to build competence. General litigation background but no privacy-specific experience.

messages.content: I'm a 5th-year litigator and my firm wants me to start handling data privacy matters. I need to get up to speed.
I have about 3 months before the first matters come in. I know nothing about privacy law beyond what I read in the news. No GDPR, no CCPA, nothing.

expected: Asks about the specific areas of privacy law the firm expects (US state laws, GDPR, sectoral regs)
Builds a phased curriculum starting with foundational overview
Includes primary sources (CCPA, GDPR, key regulations)
Includes practical components (sample privacy assessments, drafting exercises)
Fits within the 3-month timeline with realistic time estimates

conversation.content: I'm a 5th-year litigator and my firm wants me to start handling data privacy matters. I need to get up to speed.

Let me ask a few quick questions before I build your curriculum — the answers will shape the depth and prioritization significantly.

**1. What kind of matters are coming in?**
- Breach response and litigation?
- Compliance counseling (privacy programs, policies, vendor contracts)?
- Regulatory defense (FTC, state AG, CPPA)?
- All of the above?

**2. What industries are your clients in?**
Privacy law is highly sector-specific. Healthcare (HIPAA), financial services (GLBA), adtech, and general commercial companies each have different regulatory exposure. Knowing your client base tells me which frameworks to prioritize.

**3. Geography?**
- Primarily U.S.-based clients, or do you have international exposure (EU/GDPR)?
- California clients specifically? (CCPA/CPRA has its own enforcement apparatus and is often the first state law practitioners need to master.)

**4. What's your actual timeline?**
You mentioned a few months — but is there a specific matter or client pitch coming up in the near term that's driving urgency? "A few months to build general competence" and "I have a client call in three weeks" call for different sequencing.

**5. Any existing exposure?**
Have you touched privacy at all — discovery disputes involving data, a HIPAA business associate agreement, a breach notification letter? Even tangential exposure tells me where you're starting from.

The more specific you can be, the more targeted I can make this. That said, if you want me to build a general U.S. data privacy curriculum now and we refine from there, I can do that too.
I have about 3 months before the first matters come in. I know nothing about privacy law beyond what I read in the news. No GDPR, no CCPA, nothing.

That's actually a good position to be in — three months is enough time to build real competence if you're systematic about it, and starting from zero means no bad habits to unlearn.

I still need two more answers before I build this out properly:

**1. What kind of work is coming in?**

This is the most important question. The curriculum for a breach response litigator looks very different from the curriculum for a compliance counselor drafting privacy programs. Even a rough sense helps:

- **Transactional/compliance**: Privacy policies, data processing agreements, vendor contracts, building client privacy programs
- **Breach response**: Incident response, notification obligations, regulatory investigations, follow-on litigation
- **Regulatory defense**: FTC enforcement, state AG actions, CPPA proceedings
- **Some mix** — and if so, which is likely to dominate?

Your litigation background is a genuine asset for breach response and regulatory defense work. If that's where the matters are coming from, I'll weight the curriculum accordingly.

**2. What industries are your clients in?**

Even a general answer helps. "Mostly mid-market commercial companies" is different from "healthcare" or "tech/adtech." Sector-specific overlays (HIPAA, GLBA, COPPA) can add significant complexity and may need their own curriculum track.

---

If you genuinely don't know yet what's coming in, tell me that — I'll build a foundational curriculum that covers the core U.S. framework first and flags where you'll need to specialize once the matters clarify.

structural.description: Agent asks about the topic, timeline, baseline knowledge, and reason for learning
structural.justification: The agent explicitly asks about or confirms all four key dimensions: topic/type of work (breach response, compliance, regulatory defense), timeline (confirmed the user's 3-month window), baseline knowledge (confirmed zero prior exposure), and reason/context (what matters are coming in and client industries), satisfying the requirement of addressing at least three of the specified criteria before building the curriculum.

structural.description: Agent identifies the essential elements of competence in the target area
structural.justification: The agent spends both responses asking clarifying questions without ever naming the key concepts, governing sources, or practical skills that define competence in data privacy law before presenting a curriculum.

structural.description: Curriculum is organized into Foundation, Depth, Practice, and Currency phases
structural.justification: The agent has not yet built any curriculum — it is still in the intake/questioning phase and has not presented any sequenced phases or stages with different learning objectives.

structural.description: Each recommended resource includes a description, rationale, and priority level
structural.justification: The agent has not yet recommended any resources in this conversation, so there are no resources to evaluate for descriptions, rationales, or priority levels.

structural.description: Output is a structured document with learning goal, phases, time estimates, and sequence
structural.justification: The agent has not yet produced any structured curriculum document with learning goals, phases, time estimates, or sequenced resources — it is still in the information-gathering phase asking clarifying questions.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum respects the attorney's limited time and prioritizes high-impact resources
pedagogical.justification: The agent has now asked clarifying questions across two full exchanges without providing any substantive curriculum content, and given that the user has already stated they have 3 months and zero background knowledge, continuing to withhold a foundational curriculum while pressing for more specifics wastes the attorney's limited time rather than respecting it.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum includes practical exercises or skills, not just reading
pedagogical.justification: The agent has spent two full exchanges asking clarifying questions without introducing any practical exercises, skills, or hands-on learning components, suggesting the curriculum will be reading-heavy rather than practice-oriented.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum offers a shortcut or "if time is limited" path for urgent timelines
pedagogical.justification: The agent never offers a minimum-viable-path or 'if time is limited' shortcut, and instead continues asking clarifying questions across both turns without providing any prioritized fast-track option despite the user having already given a clear timeline of three months.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum identifies ongoing sources for staying current after initial learning
pedagogical.justification: The agent has not yet provided any curriculum content, let alone identified ongoing sources for staying current, as it is still in the intake/questioning phase of the conversation.

anti_patterns.description: Agent teaches the substantive law rather than creating a learning plan
anti_patterns.justification: The agent asks diagnostic questions and offers to build a curriculum/learning plan rather than teaching any substantive privacy law doctrine itself.

anti_patterns.description: Agent recommends a curriculum requiring hundreds of hours for someone with a short timeline
anti_patterns.justification: The agent has not yet built or recommended any curriculum with time estimates — it is still gathering information before making recommendations, so there is no unrealistic time estimate to evaluate.

anti_patterns.description: Agent fails to include governing statutes, regulations, or key cases
anti_patterns.justification: The agent has not yet built a curriculum — it is still in the intake/scoping phase asking clarifying questions — so there is no curriculum to evaluate for the presence or absence of primary legal sources.
